ww_strict.pm

00001 package ww_strict;
00002 
00003 $strict::VERSION = "1.03";
00004 
00005 =head1 NAME
00006 
00007 strict - Perl pragma to restrict unsafe constructs
00008 
00009 =head1 SYNOPSIS
00010 
00011     use strict;
00012 
00013     use strict "vars";
00014     use strict "refs";
00015     use strict "subs";
00016 
00017     use strict;
00018     no strict "vars";
00019 
00020 =head1 DESCRIPTION
00021 
00022 If no import list is supplied, all possible restrictions are assumed.
00023 (This is the safest mode to operate in, but is sometimes too strict for
00024 casual programming.)  Currently, there are three possible things to be
00025 strict about:  "subs", "vars", and "refs".
00026 
00027 =over 6
00028 
00029 =item C<strict refs>
00030 
00031 This generates a runtime error if you 
00032 use symbolic references (see L<perlref>).
00033 
00034     use strict 'refs';
00035     $ref = \$foo;
00036     print $$ref;    # ok
00037     $ref = "foo";
00038     print $$ref;    # runtime error; normally ok
00039     $file = "STDOUT";
00040     print $file "Hi!";  # error; note: no comma after $file
00041 
00042 =item C<strict vars>
00043 
00044 This generates a compile-time error if you access a variable that wasn't
00045 declared via "our" or C<use vars>,
00046 localized via C<my()>, or wasn't fully qualified.  Because this is to avoid
00047 variable suicide problems and subtle dynamic scoping issues, a merely
00048 local() variable isn't good enough.  See L<perlfunc/my> and
00049 L<perlfunc/local>.
00050 
00051     use strict 'vars';
00052     $X::foo = 1;     # ok, fully qualified
00053     my $foo = 10;    # ok, my() var
00054     local $foo = 9;  # blows up
00055 
00056     package Cinna;
00057     our $bar;           # Declares $bar in current package
00058     $bar = 'HgS';       # ok, global declared via pragma
00059 
00060 The local() generated a compile-time error because you just touched a global
00061 name without fully qualifying it.
00062 
00063 Because of their special use by sort(), the variables $a and $b are
00064 exempted from this check.
00065 
00066 =item C<strict subs>
00067 
00068 This disables the poetry optimization, generating a compile-time error if
00069 you try to use a bareword identifier that's not a subroutine, unless it
00070 appears in curly braces or on the left hand side of the "=E<gt>" symbol.
00071 
00072 
00073     use strict 'subs';
00074     $SIG{PIPE} = Plumber;       # blows up
00075     $SIG{PIPE} = "Plumber";     # just fine: bareword in curlies always ok
00076     $SIG{PIPE} = \&Plumber;     # preferred form
00077 
00078 
00079 
00080 =back
00081 
00082 See L<perlmodlib/Pragmatic Modules>.
00083 
00084 
00085 =cut
00086 
00087 $strict::VERSION = "1.01";
00088 
00089 my %bitmask = (
00090 refs => 0x00000002,
00091 subs => 0x00000200,
00092 vars => 0x00000400
00093 );
00094 
00095 sub bits {
00096     my $bits = 0;
00097     my @wrong;
00098     foreach my $s (@_) {
00099     push @wrong, $s unless exists $bitmask{$s};
00100         $bits |= $bitmask{$s} || 0;
00101     }
00102     if (@wrong) {
00103         #require Carp;
00104         Carp::croak("Unknown 'strict' tag(s) '@wrong'");
00105     }
00106     $bits;
00107 }
00108 
00109 my $default_bits = bits(qw(refs subs vars));
00110 
00111 sub import {
00112     shift;
00113     $^H |= @_ ? bits(@_) : $default_bits;
00114 }
00115 
00116 sub unimport {
00117     shift;
00118     $^H &= ~ bits(@_ ? @_ : qw(refs subs vars));
00119 }
00120 
00121 1;
00122 __END__
00123
